text:
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name ____________________________
Present Address ____________________________
Pioneer Address ____________________________
Year you came to Saskatchewan _______1905____

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?  
   *twelve*
   
   How many of these were bachelor's homes?
   
2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?  
   *not very often* - they came to our house, as it was larger.
   
3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?  
   *any day*
   
4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?  
   *without an invitation*
   
   What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?  
   *afternoon until late evening.*
   
   What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?  
   Visiting always included a meal.
   
   How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?  
   (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)  
   *"Stay and eat with us"*  
   Whatever we had was willingly shared.
   
   If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?  
   *bread and butter, cake and cookies, tea.*
   
5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?  
   *Someone stayed home.*
   
6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?  
   *yes*
   
   Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.  
   Mainly building bees.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.  
   *There were none.*
   
   Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.  
   *Yes*
   
   Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?  
   *No*
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHITECTS QUESTIONNAIRES,
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITTING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough for visiting back and forth?
2. How many of these were bachelor's homes?
3. How often did you usually visit neighbors?
4. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days?
5. Any day
6. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Without an invitation

What time of the day did you go—in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon until have evening?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

Visiting always included a meal.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?

(That is, was the germ to "take pol'lick" used, or was some other expression common?)

"Stay and eat with us?"

Whatever we had was willingly shared.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

Bread and butter, cake and cookies, tea.

5. Did whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

Someone stayed home.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

Mainly building bees.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe:

There were none.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Yes

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?

No
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc. if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

Town hall was used.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Not much

9. When was your first community hall built?

1919

What material was it made of? lumber

How large was it? 60' by 32'

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? community enterprise

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

In the village by village and community

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

hall was used for everything.

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

entire family attended.

How were babies and small children provided for?

Put in the bedrooms.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

Put in the barn.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Pitt Old Maid Authors

Was there card playing for a prize?

no.

What dances were popular?

Square dancing.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

No.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

It was not popular in this district, nor was dancing. Most of the people frowned upon it either in the home or in the hall.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pianist, etc.) If you have not described these on the School Questionnaire, give dates.

Town hall was used.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Not much

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? How large was it? 60' by 32'

Was it built in the village or town? By whom? By village and community enterprise

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social entertainments and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you ever attend to any other local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other gatherings, etc.? )

How was the hall used for everything?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 9), who attended? Did the entire family attend?

Put in the bedrooms.

How were babies and small children provided for?

Put in the barn.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Pitt Old Maid Authors

Was there card playing for a prize?

No.

What dances were popular?

Square dancing.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

No.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

It was not popular in this district, nor was dancing. Most of the people frowned upon it either in the home or in the hall.
12. Had attended at formality, or "smash," do you remember in small homes, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremoniously in parlor, etc.? No "putting on the dog."

13. Was the obituary known in your community? Yes

Describe what you remember about obituaries, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Every married couple was culvered, and given a gift. These varied, often the night of the wedding. Much noise making, always taken in and given a piece of wedding cake. Came in and talked a little while, then went home.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Most parties put only Adult Sunday School Class. This was in a home. Outstanding one was a Spider Web party.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS:

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Young Men's Football and Baseball Club

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

1906

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? No

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

Red Cross 1914 war work everybody.
Patriotic Society 1914 war work everybody belonged.
Beatty Soldiers Benefit league 1914 sent parcels monthly to Beatty district boys overseas. Everyone.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?
ice cream booth put up in local stores each Saturday night.
suppers.
picnics.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?
Wallace's store.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? no.
Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.
Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? ball, marbles, fly kites

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? skipping rope, play house,
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914. What purposes did they serve? How did they operate? What was their relationship to the church? Did they have any connection with the school district?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? (e.g., bazaars, fairs, etc.)

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks or foreign literature, etc.? If so, describe them.

21. What games did boys play in summer (e.g., baseball, football, marbles, etc.)? What games did girls play in summer (e.g., skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

22. Did you often have magic lantern shows? Who provided the lantern and the slides? What were the slides about?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
snow shoeing.

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
checkers, crokinole, Authors, other card games.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
whole family

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
lots of time in the winter.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
no

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?  
Give year and month if possible.  
July 1906

26. Who organized it?  
Sunday school

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
Sunday school which was the entire community.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
yes  
If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
ball, football, races.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
general lunch.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
salads, sandwiches, pie, cake, cookies, lemonade, tea.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
two til nine.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 
   Snow shoveling, 
   What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families," 
   checkers, crokinole, Authors, other word games.

23. Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain. 
   Whole family

24. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind 
   of work? Explain. Lots of time in the winter.

25. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrow-
   heads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

26. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 
   Give year and month if possible.

27. Who organized it? 
   Sunday school

28. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school 
   district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 
   Sunday school which was the entire community.

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, 
   etc.)? Ball, football, races.

30. That arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did 
   families and friends form smaller groups? General lunch.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 
   Salads, sandwiches, pie, cake, cookies, lemonade, tea.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 
   Two till nine.
32. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.
   amount of food outstanding - everyone brought their best.
   number of people - everyone came.
   nail driving race - women showed great skill.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days,
   such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family
   picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities,
   food and drink, when held, etc.
   Sunday school picnic eventually branched into a community picnic.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible,
   give dates when changes became noticeable.
   A gradual change until now the Sports' Day for money making purposes to support the Memorial Rink.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years,
   telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).
   Football - young men.
   Baseball - young men
   Tug of war - men and women

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?
   Baseball.
   What year? 1906 How long did it continue? to this day.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).
   1927. for hockey and skating
   When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
   1936. Curling.
31. Describe any features of this picnic which you consider as outstanding.

32. Describe any different kinds of games which you know of in the early days, such as the large community playing, school or Sunday school, family, foot and cricket, etc., etc.

33. Sunday school picnics eventually branched into a community picnic.

34. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

A gradual change until now the Sports' Day for money making purposes to support the Memorial Rink.

35. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (boys, women, mostly).

Football - young men.
Baseball - young men.
Tug of war - men and women.

36. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? 1906

37. How long did it continue? to this day.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1911, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

1927. for hockey and skating

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

1936. Curling.
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such
   as May 24th or July 1st).
   In the month of June.

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known
    hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.
    no.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the
    names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many
    books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)
    school books, possibly a few children's stories.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
    What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?
    had plenty of reading material in our house.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.
    The older girls, being school teachers, kept us supplied with
    reading material.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?
    Jane Eyre. The Wide World Elsie Insmore(and sequels)

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?
    Give details and dates.
    travelling library in the school now. Regional Library in Beatty now
    for the past two years.

48. Was there a school library? Yes
    When was it begun? 1907
    To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to
    read at home? didn't

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading
    material? yes
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community games?
   Who was responsible for organizing the first sports day?
   When was the sports day usually held? (that month, or any special day, such as May 25th or July 1st)
   In the month of June.

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING:

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors, if possible; tell us how many you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

school books, fortunately a few children's stories.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

had plenty of reading material in our house.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

The older girls, being school teachers, kept us supplied with reading material.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

Jane Eyre. The Wide World. Elsie A. Inmore (and sequels)

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?

Give details and dates. In the school now. Regional Library in Beatty now for the past two years.

48. Was there a school library? Yes

When was it begun? 1907

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? Didn't

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Yes
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?  
   No.

   When was it started?  
   Who started it?

   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   Family Herald
   Free Press
   The Witness

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.
   Added daily papers and various magazines when they began.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?  
   No.

   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   None

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
   No.
8. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? If so:

- When was it started?
- In what year did it exist?
- If still exists, when was it discontinued?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, etc.

9. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

- Family Herald
- Free Press
- The Witness

10. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you dropped certain subscriptions and added others.

- Added daily papers and various magazines when they began.

11. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?

- Yes
- No

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

12. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

- None

13. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship?

- Yes
- No
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?
   organ, violin, flute

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?
   guitar, accordion, violins,

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give
   dates, prices, if possible, and tell where you bought them.
   piano $200.00 from Dill in Prince Albert, 1943
   mandolin $15.00 Eaton's 1909
   autoharp $5.00 Eaton's 1915

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.
   Large part. Sang for pleasure, not for knowledge. When company came, music was always part of the entertainment, and if the company had any musical instrument, they always brought it along and the evening was spent in music.

   In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe. All parties included community singing.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?
   Camptown Races. -Stephen Foster songs.
   Clementine. On the Banks of the Wabash.

   In the community? same ones.

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain. An English community with little folk-songs.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.
   It was often done.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started?
   Who started it? How long did it continue?

   How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?

   What instruments were included?

   Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
Musical Entertainment

5a. What musical instruments did you bring with you?

5b. What musical instruments did any of your neighbors have?

5c. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates.

5d. Did you purchase any musical instruments in the last five years? If so, what were they?

5e. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your house entertainments in early years? In the West? Describe.

Large part—Sang for pleasure, not for knowledge. When company came, music was always part of the entertainment, and at the company had been spent in music. Usually, they always brought their own and the evening was spent in music. Sometimes there was a group singing at parties, etc.) Describe. All parties included community singing.

6a. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

Camp Town Races, Stephen Foster songs, Clementine, On the Banks of the Wabash.

In the community? same ones.

6b. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

An English community with little folk-songs.

6c. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke or somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

Or was often done.

6d. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? How many were in it? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

no.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

more important. More training given, in churches, and children taking music lessons.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? no.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain. no.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

No

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. To make an important but less important, in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

66. Do you have any collections, such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Yes or No.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you have been interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Yes or No. Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.? No

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
No. 613 S

If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.

Spécifiez si vous voulez des agrafes Slimtrim.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
